simulation.init¶

Source: src\simulation\__init__.py

Module Overview¶

Professional simulation framework for control engineering applications.

This module provides a comprehensive simulation framework with:

  • Multiple execution strategies (sequential, batch, parallel, real-time)

  • Advanced numerical integration methods (adaptive and fixed-step)

  • Comprehensive safety monitoring and constraint enforcement

  • Professional result processing and analysis

  • Extensible architecture for research and production use

For backward compatibility, legacy interfaces are maintained.

Complete Source Code¶

  1#======================================================================================\\\
  2#============================= src/simulation/__init__.py =============================\\\
  3#======================================================================================\\\
  4
  5"""Professional simulation framework for control engineering applications.
  6
  7This module provides a comprehensive simulation framework with:
  8- Multiple execution strategies (sequential, batch, parallel, real-time)
  9- Advanced numerical integration methods (adaptive and fixed-step)
 10- Comprehensive safety monitoring and constraint enforcement
 11- Professional result processing and analysis
 12- Extensible architecture for research and production use
 13
 14For backward compatibility, legacy interfaces are maintained.
 15"""
 16
 17# =============================================================================
 18# NEW FRAMEWORK INTERFACES
 19# =============================================================================
 20
 21# Core framework components
 22from .core import (
 23    SimulationEngine, Integrator, Orchestrator, SimulationStrategy,
 24    SafetyGuard, ResultContainer, SimulationContext, StateSpaceUtilities, TimeManager
 25)
 26
 27# Orchestrators for different execution strategies
 28from .orchestrators import (
 29    SequentialOrchestrator, BatchOrchestrator, ParallelOrchestrator, RealTimeOrchestrator
 30)
 31
 32# Integration methods
 33from .integrators import (
 34    ForwardEuler, RungeKutta4, DormandPrince45, ZeroOrderHold
 35)
 36
 37# Safety and monitoring
 38from .safety import (
 39    apply_safety_guards, SafetyViolationError, SafetyMonitor, PerformanceMonitor
 40)
 41
 42# Result management
 43from .results import (
 44    StandardResultContainer, BatchResultContainer, ResultProcessor
 45)
 46
 47# Analysis strategies
 48from .strategies import (
 49    MonteCarloStrategy,
 50)
 51
 52# =============================================================================
 53# BACKWARD COMPATIBILITY INTERFACES
 54# =============================================================================
 55
 56# Legacy imports from old structure (maintaining exact same interface)
 57from .orchestrators.sequential import get_step_fn, step, run_simulation
 58from .core.simulation_context import SimulationContext
 59
 60# Legacy vector simulation interface
 61from .orchestrators.batch import simulate_batch as simulate
 62
 63# Legacy adaptive integration
 64from .integrators.adaptive.runge_kutta import rk45_step
 65
 66# Legacy safety guards (exact original interface)
 67from .safety.guards import (
 68    guard_no_nan as _guard_no_nan,
 69    guard_energy as _guard_energy,
 70    guard_bounds as _guard_bounds
 71)
 72
 73# =============================================================================
 74# EXPORTS
 75# =============================================================================
 76
 77# New framework exports
 78__all__ = [
 79    # Core interfaces
 80    "SimulationEngine", "Integrator", "Orchestrator", "SimulationStrategy",
 81    "SafetyGuard", "ResultContainer", "SimulationContext",
 82    "StateSpaceUtilities", "TimeManager",
 83
 84    # Orchestrators
 85    "SequentialOrchestrator", "BatchOrchestrator", "ParallelOrchestrator", "RealTimeOrchestrator",
 86
 87    # Integrators
 88    "ForwardEuler", "RungeKutta4", "DormandPrince45", "ZeroOrderHold",
 89
 90    # Safety
 91    "apply_safety_guards", "SafetyViolationError", "SafetyMonitor", "PerformanceMonitor",
 92
 93    # Results
 94    "StandardResultContainer", "BatchResultContainer", "ResultProcessor",
 95
 96    # Strategies
 97    "MonteCarloStrategy",
 98
 99    # Legacy compatibility (IMPORTANT: maintain exact same names)
100    "get_step_fn",           # Original function from simulation_runner
101    "step",                  # Original step function
102    "run_simulation",        # Original simulation runner
103    "simulate",              # Original vector simulation function
104    "rk45_step",             # Original adaptive integration function
105]
106
107# =============================================================================
108# CONVENIENCE FACTORY FUNCTIONS
109# =============================================================================
110
111def create_simulation_engine(engine_type: str = "sequential", config_path: str = "config.yaml"):
112    """Create a simulation engine of specified type.
113
114    Parameters
115    ----------
116    engine_type : str, optional
117        Type of engine: 'sequential', 'batch', 'parallel', 'real_time'
118    config_path : str, optional
119        Path to configuration file
120
121    Returns
122    -------
123    SimulationEngine
124        Configured simulation engine
125    """
126    context = SimulationContext(config_path)
127    return context.create_simulation_engine(engine_type)
128
129
130def run_monte_carlo_analysis(simulation_fn, n_samples: int = 1000, **kwargs):
131    """Run Monte Carlo analysis on simulation function.
132
133    Parameters
134    ----------
135    simulation_fn : callable
136        Simulation function to analyze
137    n_samples : int, optional
138        Number of Monte Carlo samples
139    **kwargs
140        Additional parameters for analysis
141
142    Returns
143    -------
144    dict
145        Monte Carlo analysis results
146    """
147    strategy = MonteCarloStrategy(n_samples=n_samples)
148    return strategy.analyze(simulation_fn, kwargs)
149
150
151# Add convenience functions to exports
152__all__.extend([
153    "create_simulation_engine",
154    "run_monte_carlo_analysis"
155])

Functions¶

create_simulation_engine(engine_type, config_path)¶

Create a simulation engine of specified type.

Parameters¶

engine_type : str, optional Type of engine: ‘sequential’, ‘batch’, ‘parallel’, ‘real_time’ config_path : str, optional Path to configuration file

Returns¶

SimulationEngine Configured simulation engine

Source Code¶

 1def create_simulation_engine(engine_type: str = "sequential", config_path: str = "config.yaml"):
 2    """Create a simulation engine of specified type.
 3
 4    Parameters
 5    ----------
 6    engine_type : str, optional
 7        Type of engine: 'sequential', 'batch', 'parallel', 'real_time'
 8    config_path : str, optional
 9        Path to configuration file
10
11    Returns
12    -------
13    SimulationEngine
14        Configured simulation engine
15    """
16    context = SimulationContext(config_path)
17    return context.create_simulation_engine(engine_type)

run_monte_carlo_analysis(simulation_fn, n_samples)¶

Run Monte Carlo analysis on simulation function.

Parameters¶

simulation_fn : callable Simulation function to analyze n_samples : int, optional Number of Monte Carlo samples **kwargs Additional parameters for analysis

Returns¶

dict Monte Carlo analysis results

Source Code¶

 1def run_monte_carlo_analysis(simulation_fn, n_samples: int = 1000, **kwargs):
 2    """Run Monte Carlo analysis on simulation function.
 3
 4    Parameters
 5    ----------
 6    simulation_fn : callable
 7        Simulation function to analyze
 8    n_samples : int, optional
 9        Number of Monte Carlo samples
10    **kwargs
11        Additional parameters for analysis
12
13    Returns
14    -------
15    dict
16        Monte Carlo analysis results
17    """
18    strategy = MonteCarloStrategy(n_samples=n_samples)
19    return strategy.analyze(simulation_fn, kwargs)
